title: Deuteronomy Chapter 25 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 25 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 25 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 25.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25:1, what is the role of the judges when men come unto judgment?
options: To justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: To justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:1 states that judges shall justify the righteous and condemn the wicked when men come unto judgment.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of stripes a judge may give according to Deuteronomy 25:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Forty stripes
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:3 specifies that a judge may give forty stripes, but not exceed this number.

questions.question: What should not be done to an ox when it treads out the corn, as stated in Deuteronomy 25:4?
options: You shall not muzzle the ox
You shall not feed the ox
You shall not tie the ox
You shall not water the ox
questions.correctAnswer: You shall not muzzle the ox
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:4 commands that the ox should not be muzzled when treading out the corn.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25:5, if a man dies without a child, who should marry his widow?
questions.correctAnswer: Her husband's brother
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:5 states that the husband's brother shall marry the widow if the man died without a child.

questions.question: What is the name given to the firstborn child of the widow and her husband's brother, according to Deuteronomy 25:6?
options: He shall succeed in the name of his dead brother
He shall be named after his father
He shall inherit the land directly
He shall be called the son of God
questions.correctAnswer: He shall succeed in the name of his dead brother
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:6 explains that the firstborn will succeed in the name of his dead brother to keep his name in Israel.

questions.question: What action does the widow take if the brother refuses to marry her, as described in Deuteronomy 25:7?
options: She goes to the elders at the gate
questions.correctAnswer: She goes to the elders at the gate
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:7 says the widow shall go to the gate to the elders if the brother refuses to marry her.

questions.question: What does the brother's wife do to the man who refuses to marry her, according to Deuteronomy 25:9?
options: Looses his shoe, spits in his face, and declares a curse
Throws him out of the city
questions.correctAnswer: Looses his shoe, spits in his face, and declares a curse
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:9 describes that she shall loose his shoe, spit in his face, and say a curse before the elders.

questions.question: What name shall be called in Israel for the man who has his shoe loosed, according to Deuteronomy 25:10?
options: The house of him that hath his shoe loosed
questions.correctAnswer: The house of him that hath his shoe loosed
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:10 says his name in Israel shall be called 'The house of him that hath his shoe loosed.'

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25:12, what is the consequence if a woman grabs a man's private parts during a fight to rescue her husband?
options: Her hand shall be cut off
questions.correctAnswer: Her hand shall be cut off
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:12 commands that the woman's hand shall be cut off without pity if she grabs the man's private parts.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 25:15 instructs to have both large and small weights for trading.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:15 instructs to have perfect and just weights and measures, not diverse weights.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 25:17 commands the Israelites to remember what Amalek did to them after they came out of Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:17 specifically commands to remember what Amalek did by the way after they came out of Egypt.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 25:19 says the Israelites should forget the deeds of Amalek once they have rest.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:19 commands the Israelites to blot out the remembrance of Amalek but never to forget it.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Deuteronomy 25:13: 'Thou shalt not have in thy bag divers ______, a great and a small.'
questions.correctAnswer: weights
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:13 states that divers weights, a great and a small, should not be in thy bag.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25:16, what are all who do unrighteous things considered to be before the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: An abomination
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:16 says all who do unrighteous things are an abomination unto the LORD.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25:18, whom did Amalek attack?
options: The hindmost and feeble behind the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: The hindmost and feeble behind the Israelites
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:18 states that Amalek smote the hindmost and all feeble behind when Israel was faint and weary.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 25 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 25 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 25:1 teach us about God's justice in resolving disputes among believers?
options: Judges must justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
All disputes should be ignored to maintain peace
Believers should settle disputes privately without judges
The wicked should always be forgiven without judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Judges must justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:1 emphasizes that in controversy, judges must discern and justify the righteous while condemning the wicked, showing God's justice in judgment. This teaches believers to seek fairness and truth in disputes.

questions.question: What principle about discipline does Deuteronomy 25:3 teach regarding correction within the community?
options: Discipline should not exceed forty stripes to avoid causing contempt
Discipline should be as harsh as possible to deter sin
No discipline is necessary among believers
Discipline should be performed secretly without witnesses
questions.correctAnswer: Discipline should not exceed forty stripes to avoid causing contempt
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:3 sets a limit of forty stripes in discipline, teaching moderation and respect even in correction so that the brother is not despised, illustrating a balance of justice and compassion.

questions.question: How does the command in Deuteronomy 25:4 about not muzzling the ox teach us about honesty and fairness in work?
options: Workers deserve to benefit from their labor, symbolized by allowing the ox to eat
Animals should never be fed in the field
Owners should keep all benefits from workers' labor
The ox is not important in agricultural work
questions.correctAnswer: Workers deserve to benefit from their labor, symbolized by allowing the ox to eat
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:4 instructs not to muzzle the ox while treading out the corn, which symbolizes treating workers fairly and allowing them to share in the fruits of their labor, teaching integrity and generosity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25:5-6, what responsibility does a brother have toward his deceased brother's wife and name?
options: He should marry the widow and raise up offspring to preserve his brother's name
He should allow the widow to marry anyone she wishes
He should leave the widow unmarried permanently
He should sell the widow's property
questions.correctAnswer: He should marry the widow and raise up offspring to preserve his brother's name
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 6 explain the duty of levirate marriage where a brother marries his deceased brother's widow to maintain the brother's lineage and name in Israel, teaching about family responsibility and legacy.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 25:7-10 teach about honor and responsibility within family relationships when a brother refuses to marry the widow?
options: The refusal results in a public act of shame involving shoe removal and spitting
The brother is celebrated for his choice
The widow must leave the family without recourse
The refusal is ignored and forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: The refusal results in a public act of shame involving shoe removal and spitting
questions.explanation: These verses describe a ritual to shame a brother who refuses to fulfill his duty, illustrating the importance of honoring family obligations and the consequences of neglecting God's commands in family life.

questions.question: In a situation where a wife intervenes violently to rescue her husband (Deuteronomy 25:11-12), what principle about justice and personal boundaries is taught?
options: She shall lose her hand as a consequence of inappropriate intervention
The husband should be left to fight alone
No punishment is necessary for the wife
questions.correctAnswer: She shall lose her hand as a consequence of inappropriate intervention
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 teach the seriousness of violating personal boundaries and using violence improperly, showing that even well-intended actions must respect justice and order.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 25:13-15 teach about honesty in business dealings?
options: Use of just weights and measures is commanded to ensure fairness
It is acceptable to cheat with differing weights
Weights and measures are unimportant in commerce
Only large weights should be used to gain advantage
questions.correctAnswer: Use of just weights and measures is commanded to ensure fairness
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize the importance of integrity in business by forbidding dishonest weights and measures, promoting honesty and fairness which lead to God's blessing.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 25:16 describe God's view of unrighteous behavior in commerce and judgment?
options: Unrighteousness in these areas is an abomination to the LORD
God is indifferent to business practices
Dishonest deeds are acceptable if no one is harmed
questions.correctAnswer: Unrighteousness in these areas is an abomination to the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 16 makes clear that God detests unrighteousness in both judgment and trade, highlighting the call for holiness and integrity in all aspects of life.

questions.question: What spiritual lesson can we learn from the remembrance of Amalek's attack described in Deuteronomy 25:17-19?
options: Believers must remember and act against persistent evil to maintain faithfulness
We should forgive and forget all enemies immediately
Attacks from enemies are to be ignored
God does not require remembrance of past evils
questions.correctAnswer: Believers must remember and act against persistent evil to maintain faithfulness
questions.explanation: The passage teaches the importance of remembering Amalek's evil to ensure it is not forgotten and to maintain vigilance against persistent sin and opposition to God.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with honesty at work. Based on Deuteronomy 25, what biblical truth would you share about integrity?
options: Use just weights and measures to remain honest and please God
Cheating is acceptable as long as it benefits you
Honesty is not emphasized in Scripture
Disguise dishonest actions to avoid punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Use just weights and measures to remain honest and please God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:13-15 instructs believers to use honest weights and measures, teaching that integrity in daily work honors God and brings blessing.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 25:4 encourage us to show kindness and fairness in our daily work?
options: Do not muzzle the ox while it treads the corn, allowing it to eat
Animals should be worked to exhaustion
questions.correctAnswer: Do not muzzle the ox while it treads the corn, allowing it to eat
questions.explanation: This verse teaches that workers, even animals, deserve fair treatment and benefit from their labor, encouraging kindness and justice in work ethics.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 25:2-3, a judge may impose any number of stripes as punishment without limit.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 2-3 limit the number of stripes to forty to prevent excessive punishment and maintain respect for the individual, teaching moderation in discipline.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 25:7-10 shows that refusing family responsibilities has social consequences within the community.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: These verses describe a public act of shame for a man refusing to marry his brother's widow, teaching that neglecting family duties leads to community accountability.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 25:6 says the firstborn son born to the widow shall succeed in the name of his _____ which is dead.
questions.correctAnswer: brother
questions.explanation: Verse 6 explains that the firstborn son represents the deceased brother's name, preserving his family line in Israel.

questions.question: How can Deuteronomy 25:11-12 guide us in controlling anger and avoiding harmful actions during conflict?
options: Avoid violent, impulsive actions even when defending loved ones
Use any means necessary to protect family members
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid violent, impulsive actions even when defending loved ones
questions.explanation: These verses warn against impulsive violence, teaching self-control and respect for justice during conflict, even in defense of family.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 25:19 teach about God's command regarding persistent enemies?
options: Blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven and do not forget
Forgive all enemies immediately without remembrance
Ignore enemy actions and focus on personal gain
Allow enemies to live without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: Blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven and do not forget
questions.explanation: Verse 19 commands Israel to remember Amalek's evil and to blot it out, emphasizing spiritual vigilance and obedience to God's justice.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 25 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 25.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25:3, what is the maximum number of stripes a judge may give to a wicked man?
questions.correctAnswer: 40 stripes
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:3 explicitly states that a judge may give forty stripes and not exceed this number to avoid making the brother appear vile.

questions.question: What principle related to fair trade is taught in Deuteronomy 25:13-15?
options: Using varied weights and measures to test honesty
Having perfect and just weights and measures to ensure fairness
Allowing merchants to decide their own weights
Ignoring weights and measures in business
questions.correctAnswer: Having perfect and just weights and measures to ensure fairness
questions.explanation: Verses 13-15 command that one should have perfect and just weights and measures, emphasizing honesty and justice in commerce.

questions.question: In the levirate marriage law described in Deuteronomy 25:5-10, if a man refuses to marry his brother's widow, what symbolic act does she perform?
options: She removes his sandal and spits in his face
She offers sacrifice at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: She removes his sandal and spits in his face
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes the widow loosening his shoe and spitting in his face as a public symbol of his refusal to raise up his brother's name.

questions.question: What is the stated reason for not muzzling the ox while it treads out the corn, according to Deuteronomy 25:4?
options: To allow the ox to rest
So the ox can eat as it works
questions.correctAnswer: So the ox can eat as it works
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:4 commands not to muzzle the ox when it treads out the corn, implying it should be allowed to eat during labor.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 25:17-19 commands Israel to remember what Amalek did. What specific action is Israel instructed to do regarding Amalek?
options: Blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven
Build a monument to remember Amalek
Invite Amalek to dwell among them
questions.correctAnswer: Blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven
questions.explanation: Verse 19 declares that when Israel has rest, it shall blot out the remembrance of Amalek completely, showing God's judgment against Amalek's attack.

questions.question: What is the consequence for a woman who intervenes in a fight by grabbing the testicles of an adversary, according to Deuteronomy 25:11-12?
options: She shall be cut off from the community
Her hand shall be cut off without pity
questions.correctAnswer: Her hand shall be cut off without pity
questions.explanation: Verse 12 prescribes that if a woman grabs a man's testicles during a fight, her hand shall be cut off, with no pity given.

questions.question: What is the underlying theme connecting the judicial instructions in Deuteronomy 25:1-3?
questions.correctAnswer: Justice and proportional punishment
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 emphasize judges must justify the righteous and condemn the wicked with punishments proportional to their faults, highlighting judicial justice.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 25:6 teaches that the firstborn son of a widow who marries her deceased husband's brother succeeds in the name of the deceased brother.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 6 clearly states the firstborn son shall succeed in the name of his deceased brother to keep his name in Israel.

questions.question: What is the significance of the shoe-loosing ceremony mentioned in Deuteronomy 25:9-10 in ancient Israelite culture?
options: It symbolizes the transfer of property
It represents a curse on the man refusing levirate duty
It is a sign of mourning
questions.correctAnswer: It represents a curse on the man refusing levirate duty
questions.explanation: The act of removing the shoe and spitting (v.9) publicly shames the man who refuses to marry his brother’s widow, symbolizing a curse and social disgrace.

questions.question: How does the command not to muzzle the ox (Deuteronomy 25:4) typologically connect to New Testament teaching?
options: It foreshadows Christ’s teaching on mercy
It parallels Paul’s instruction that workers deserve their wages
It relates to the Sabbath rest
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels Paul’s instruction that workers deserve their wages
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:4 is quoted in 1 Timothy 5:18 to affirm that laborers (like oxen) deserve to benefit from their work, a principle extended in the New Testament.

questions.question: What cultural or legal concern is addressed by the prohibition against having diverse weights and measures in Deuteronomy 25:13-14?
questions.correctAnswer: Preventing economic exploitation and dishonesty
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 forbid dishonest weights and measures to ensure fair trade and prevent exploitation in the marketplace.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 25:17-18, what is the historical significance of Amalek's attack described here?
options: It was a surprise attack on the weak and weary Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: It was a surprise attack on the weak and weary Israelites
questions.explanation: Verse 18 describes Amalek attacking the feeble hindmost of Israel when they were faint and weary, highlighting Amalek’s ruthless nature.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 25:1-2 teach about the role and responsibilities of judges in Israel?
options: Judges must justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
Judges should avoid involvement in controversies
questions.correctAnswer: Judges must justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 establish that judges are to judge fairly by justifying the righteous and condemning the wicked, showing their role as impartial arbiters.

questions.question: What is the theological implication of the command to blot out Amalek’s remembrance in Deuteronomy 25:19?
options: It reflects God's judgment on persistent evil
It is a call for reconciliation
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects God's judgment on persistent evil
questions.explanation: The command in verse 19 to blot out Amalek’s remembrance symbolizes divine judgment against Amalek’s unrepentant hostility toward Israel and God.

questions.question: Which literary device is evident in the structure of Deuteronomy 25:5-10 concerning levirate marriage?
options: Chiasm emphasizing refusal and public shame
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm emphasizing refusal and public shame
questions.explanation: The passage uses a chiastic structure highlighting the refusal of the brother (v.7-8) and the consequent public shaming ritual (v.9-10), underscoring social accountability.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 25 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 25 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25, what is the maximum number of stripes a judge may inflict upon a wicked man found worthy of beating?
questions.correctAnswer: 40 stripes
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:3 limits the beating to forty stripes to prevent excessive punishment and maintain the dignity of the person. This reflects biblical justice and mercy principles found also in 2 Corinthians 11:24 and Luke 13:14.

questions.question: What is the purpose of judges judging controversies between men as stated in Deuteronomy 25?
options: To justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: To justify the righteous and condemn the wicked
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:1 emphasizes that judges are to discern rightly, justifying the righteous and condemning the wicked, reflecting God's justice as seen also in Psalm 7:8, Isaiah 33:22, John 7:24, and Romans 2:11.

questions.question: What command is given regarding the ox that treads out the corn?
options: The ox shall not be muzzled
The ox shall be given extra grain
The ox shall be sold after work
questions.correctAnswer: The ox shall not be muzzled
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:4 commands not to muzzle the ox while it treads out the corn, teaching fairness and provision for laborers, which Paul references in 1 Timothy 5:18 regarding the right of workers to benefit from their labor.

questions.question: In the levirate marriage law stated in Deuteronomy 25, who is to marry the widow if her husband dies childless?
questions.correctAnswer: Her husband's brother
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:5 directs the husband's brother to marry the widow to raise up offspring in his brother's name, a practice emphasizing the preservation of family lineage and inheritance, also echoed in Ruth 4:5-10 and Genesis 38.

questions.question: What happens if the brother refuses to marry his deceased brother's wife?
options: She shall loose his shoe and spit in his face
questions.correctAnswer: She shall loose his shoe and spit in his face
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:9 describes a public act of shame where the widow removes the man's shoe and spits in his face if he refuses to fulfill his duty, symbolizing disgrace for neglecting family responsibility, connected to themes of honor and shame in biblical culture (Ruth 4:7-8, Proverbs 3:27).

questions.question: What is the significance of the name given to the man whose shoe is loosed?
options: He is called 'The House of the Righteous'
He is called 'The House of him that hath his shoe loosed'
questions.correctAnswer: He is called 'The House of him that hath his shoe loosed'
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:10 states that his name will be remembered as 'The house of him that hath his shoe loosed,' marking him with dishonor for not fulfilling the levirate duty, illustrating covenantal responsibilities within Israel's community (cf. Ruth 4:11).

questions.question: What punishment does Deuteronomy 25 prescribe for a woman who intervenes in a fight by grabbing a man's private parts?
options: She shall be cut off her hand
questions.correctAnswer: She shall be cut off her hand
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:12 prescribes the cutting off of the woman's hand as a severe penalty for this act, underscoring the seriousness of violating personal dignity and bodily sanctity, paralleling the principle of lex talionis in Exodus 21:23-25.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 25 command concerning weights and measures?
options: Use perfect and just weights and measures
Use heavier weights to gain profit
Use smaller measures to save goods
questions.correctAnswer: Use perfect and just weights and measures
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:13-15 commands honest trade practices by requiring just weights and measures, reflecting God's holiness and justice, also taught in Proverbs 11:1, Leviticus 19:35-36, and Amos 8:5.

questions.question: Why does Deuteronomy 25 warn against dishonest weights and measures?
options: Because they are an abomination to the LORD God
Because they are difficult to carry
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are an abomination to the LORD God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:16 calls dishonest weights and measures an abomination to God, highlighting the moral and spiritual corruption of deceit, consistent with God's character of justice revealed in Proverbs 20:23 and Micah 6:8.

questions.question: Who is Amalek and what did he do according to Deuteronomy 25?
options: An enemy who attacked the weak at the rear when Israel came out of Egypt
A priest who served in the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: An enemy who attacked the weak at the rear when Israel came out of Egypt
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:17-18 describes Amalek as an enemy who attacked Israel's feeble and weary rear during the Exodus, showing contempt for God, an event God condemns throughout Scripture, including Exodus 17:8-16 and 1 Samuel 15.

questions.question: What command does God give concerning the remembrance of Amalek?
options: To blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven
To build a monument for Amalek
questions.correctAnswer: To blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:19 commands Israel to utterly blot out Amalek's remembrance once settled in the land, symbolizing God's judgment against persistent evil, paralleled by God's call to oppose evil in Psalm 9:5-6 and Revelation 20:10.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'If brethren dwell together, and one of them die, and have no child, the wife of the dead shall not marry ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: a stranger
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:5 teaches that the widow must not marry outside the family (a stranger) but stay within the brother-in-law relationship to preserve the deceased's name, showing the emphasis on covenantal family continuity as in Genesis 38 and Ruth 4.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the command not to muzzle the ox while it treads out the corn?
options: It reflects God's justice and provision for laborers
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects God's justice and provision for laborers
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:4 teaches that workers deserve to partake in the fruits of their labor, reflecting God's justice and care, a principle also emphasized in 1 Timothy 5:18 and Luke 10:7, showing God's concern for fairness and provision.

questions.question: What does the act of loosing the shoe in Deuteronomy 25 symbolize?
options: Public shame and refusal to fulfill family duty
questions.correctAnswer: Public shame and refusal to fulfill family duty
questions.explanation: The loosing of the shoe in Deuteronomy 25:9 symbolizes public disgrace for the man refusing to marry his brother's widow, illustrating social accountability, linked to cultural customs in Ruth 4:7-8 and the importance of covenant responsibilities.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 25, what is the relationship between God's judgment and human justice as expressed in the role of judges?
options: Judges act independently of God’s will
Judges are to imitate God by justifying the righteous and condemning the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Judges are to imitate God by justifying the righteous and condemning the wicked
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 25:1 teaches that judges must discern rightly, reflecting God's perfect justice, as shown also in Isaiah 1:17, Psalm 82:3-4, and Romans 13:4, connecting divine justice with human judicial responsibility.

questions.question: What is the eschatological implication of blotting out Amalek's remembrance as commanded in Deuteronomy 25?
options: It foreshadows ultimate defeat of evil by God
It indicates the end of the Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows ultimate defeat of evil by God
questions.explanation: The command in Deuteronomy 25:19 to blot out Amalek’s memory symbolizes God's final judgment against evil, anticipatory of eschatological victory found in Revelation 20:10 and Psalm 37:9, emphasizing God’s sovereign justice over sin.
